body: Thank you for checking it @Henry-Hong
Moreover, I think we can merge it into 0.11.2 as well.

> By the way, could you please upgrade the version with proper changes for your next PR?

Sure. I’m actually considering upgrading the front-end dependencies, with a particular focus on Webpack.

The current dependencies are quite outdated, and upgrading them individually is challenging. Upgrading one dependency often requires updating others as well, which creates a cascading effect.

Followings are related issue. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ZEPPELIN-5793
ping @jongyoul @pan3793
Did I understand correctly that changes can be merged? There is a problem with Zeppelin: Livy interpreter tests, but this does not apply to changes in this branch. @jongyoul @Reamer
Thank you very much for your contribution. I see you have found more locations. If you think you have found them all, please let me know so I can do the review.

I'm generally not a fan of downgrades, at some point old versions are no longer supported and the update has to be done.
Do you see a possibility to adapt the `Gruntfile` and the `index.html` accordingly so that mathjax works in version 3.x?
@Reamer Please conduct the testing and review. :)

@jongyoul 
Yes, we can do a downgrade to restore the functionality. Could you open a JIRA ticket to update MathJX with the findings in this issue.
@tbonelee To make sure, do we assume the zeppelin home for containers is /opt/zeppelin by default?
@Reamer Created. https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ZEPPELIN-6056

### Closing (will re-open after fix)

The tests are failling. Seems like I didn't commit everything upstream.
@Henry-Hong This PR needs a rebase

> @tbonelee To make sure, do we assume the zeppelin home for containers is /opt/zeppelin by default?

Yes, I have matched the zeppelin home in the `scripts/docker/interpreter/Dockerfile` (which is based on `scripts/docker/zeppelin/bin/Dockerfile`, so it refers to the zeppelin home in that Dockerfile) with the default `zeppelin.docker.container.home` configuration value.

In practice, when the run mode is 'docker', the Zeppelin server uploads the interpreter files to the container's zeppelin home path at runtime within the interpreter Docker container, so it might not be strictly necessary to match them. However, to prevent potential conflicts, I determined it would be better to align it with the zeppelin home path of the base image(of dockerfile `scripts/docker/zeppelin/bin/Dockerfile`).

It has conflicts but this [PR](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/pull/4786) should be merged first.
Or, there'll be more conflicts again.
If no further comments are received, I will merge this pull request on Thursday.

How do you build Zeppelin? Some platforms e.g. YARN already have the Hadoop classes in the classpath as far as I remember, which is why the value is set to provided by default.
However, if you run Zeppelin in Kubernetes or Docker, for example, this is not the case. Here you have to set the profile `include-hadoop` when building. Take a look at the [Dockerfile](https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/afc4141b97827918de4465a708b59ba39692398d/Dockerfile#L24).

If you are not using YARN, I would recommend this. There is also the possibility to make the Hadoop library available with the environment variable `HADOOP_CONF_DIR` at startup.
See https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/fb64356e57c5f3e9280d6eb9cea96858efcb356a/bin/zeppelin-daemon.sh#L86-L98

Or corresponding positions in https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/bin/interpreter.sh
But I don't see anything suitable for R here. 

EDIT: The environment variables are of course only there to point to and use an existing Hadoop installation.

Hi @myongyun ，the `nzScroll` seems taking no effect in my env, the result table cannot display all the content 
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/549ee212-2498-487c-882d-6e058fc84890)

unless adding config like `overflow=auto` :
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3e6c9791-b1e0-4995-aa87-504d3f0eb2a0)

Do you have any idea to solve this?
Thanks for checking this issue! I'll try what you've suggested.

Actually, Spark hardcoding `SPARK_HOME` to `/opt/spark` and `HADOOP_CONF_DIR` to `/opt/hadoop/conf` in docker image and Spark on K8s cases, so far it works well.

I don't see any potential issues on hardcoding the `ZEPPELIN_HOME` inside the docker image, since docker already provides good isolation, to make life easier, I think we can do similar things too.
If no further comments are received, I will merge this pull request on Thursday.

@tbonelee thanks for fixing this! an additional request, since this feature is not covered by CI, could you please replace the steps in "How should this be tested?" with the copy-pastable commands? this would help reviewers to verify the functionalities locally :) thanks in advance.

> We need to mitigate `zeppelin-interpreter` dependency. Currently, `zeppelin-interpreter` is quite big and has a lot of other dependencies unrelated to interpreters.

I fully agree with that, and I also noticed the packaging time for `zeppelin-interpreter-shaded` is pretty slow due to a lot of classes needing to be relocated, and some of those deps come from ZEPPELIN-3471, I have raised a [thread](https://lists.apache.org/thread/vm2m4xg6bg0db33txrrm9ydd15dqy1lx) to remove it in the dev mailing list, please leave your comments to help the community make the decision.

> Interpreters needing communication can add `zeppelin-protocol` as a dependency. 

To address the above issue, I think we should separate the optional dependencies into individual modules, then we can eliminate them in some interpreters, but is `zeppelin-protocol` that case? I think it is required by all interpreters.

> it helps users easily run Zeppelin.

I have similar questions about it. it's unclear to me what the use case is:

is it for users to quickly explore Zeppelin with one command? if so, the ZEPPELIN_IMAGE_TAG should use the latest released one instead of the developing SNAPSHOT version, and since you are using docker compose, we just need a preset `.env` instead of `.env.template`, this also saves a copy-paste command to allow users to quickly launch the playground.

is it for developers to quickly test their changes? if so, you should leave docs to instruct developers how to apply their changes to the environment, and how to attach the process to debug.

given there was a set of scripts under `scripts/vagrant/zeppelin-dev`, I would suggest putting those docker files under `scripts/docker/zeppelin-<purpose>` instead of `docker`

@pan3793 
As with other projects, I hope the Zeppelin repository will also provide a `docker-compose.yml` file. This is to help developers easily run Zeppelin by copying or using this file. I will proceed with the necessary tasks according to your advice.

@pan3793
Thank you for the detailed review.
I've reflected your review and also made some adjustments to the "How should this be tested?" section.
Does this align with the direction you requested?
@pan3793 I have modified the path of the docker-compose file and removed the .env file for a quicker start. Please review.
Thank you for the contribution! By the way, is there any possible field with the same behaviors? I think it looks good but just in case.
By the way, the failed tests are not common. Could you please check the test and it works well in your local?
cc. @jongyoul
Thank you! I merged it.
@pan3793 kindly ping :-)
@jongyoul Just rebased and pushed!
Please ensure that the logger is also `private static final`.

Installation of packages via `yum` or `apt-get` requires `root` rights.
Maven runs without `root` rights.

I also looked at the problem with `thrift` some time ago and hoped that the Java classes could be generated with a Maven plugin. Similar to GRPC. Unfortunately, I have not found anything.


My goal was just to have the thrift files in git and generate the thrift classes each time. But due to the installation process I don't see a way to do this. How do other Thrift projects implement it?

Hi,
in my opinion `websocket-driver` should be a `devDependencies`. See the following dependency tree.
```
08:50 $ npm ls websocket-driver
zeppelin@0.0.0 /home/pdallig/git/zeppelin/zeppelin-web-angular
├─┬ @angular-devkit/build-angular@0.803.29
│ └─┬ webpack-dev-server@3.11.0
│   ├─┬ sockjs-client@1.4.0
│   │ └─┬ faye-websocket@0.11.4
│   │   └── websocket-driver@0.6.5 deduped invalid: "^0.7.4" from the root project
│   └─┬ sockjs@0.3.20
│     ├─┬ faye-websocket@0.10.0
│     │ └── websocket-driver@0.6.5 deduped invalid: "^0.7.4" from the root project
│     └── websocket-driver@0.6.5 deduped invalid: "^0.7.4" from the root project
└── websocket-driver@0.6.5 invalid: "^0.7.4" from the root project
```

I also think that we should not interfere with angular's dependencies. I think it makes more sense to update angular itself, even if this requires more work.
I agree with @Reamer on that updating Angular itself. Otherwise we'll need to take care of this single version update all throughout

Did you come up with `genthrift.sh` script all by yourself, or is there reference(or similar script) you referred to and share with us? Like @Reamer says, it would be good to refer to how other projects handle situations like this.

integrating thrift codegen into the regular build process makes the developer hard to set up the environment, because thrift community does not publish the convenient `thrift` binary on releases, the downstream developers have to build thrift from source or get from the platform package managers like apt/brew, neither ways are convenient due to additional native deps requirements or only a few of versions providing.

given the generated thrift code won't change frequently, tracking the generated thrift code and providing a script to regenerate it is a common way. I think we can make some improvements in `genthrift.sh`, for example, make it working dir agnostic, allow passing env `THRIFT_EXEC` to use a custom `thrift`
@Reamer I have set all logger constants to `private static final`. Please review this.

Thank you @Reamer and @JooHyukKim for the feedback.

I appreciate the clarification on keeping `websocket-driver` as a devDependency and the potential complications of modifying Angular’s nested dependencies. I understand why it’s better to address this issue by updating Angular itself rather than patching a single dependency.

I’ll start looking into what’s involved in updating Angular itself, as you suggested, and see how it goes. 

Thank you again.

Hello @Reamer and @JooHyukKim (and the rest of the team,)

Thank you again for your feedback on this PR. After looking into updating Angular, I’ve realized that it involves more work and checks than I initially expected. Given that this update will take some time and careful consideration, I believe it’s best to close this PR for now.

I’m looking forward to finding other areas where I can be more helpful.

Hello @kevinjmh ,

I’ve been looking into the issue you reported. I tried to reproduce the problem using a PostgreSQL database with a similar JDBC query, but everything seemed to work fine on my end-the scroll bar appeared correctly.

To better understand the issue, could you provide a bit more information such as the interpreter configuration and the database you’re using? Also, could you confirm that you’re using the updated version of Zeppelin?

Thanks for your help!

Thank you for the discussion. My first goal is to ask him to divide thrift definition and generated files with zeppelin-intepreter module to minimize itself and clean up the module. During this job, I thought it would be better to generate thrift files easier. By the way, in my past experience, I provided all binaries for thrift compilers into a repository. Can we choose a similar way? You also can use docker to build the thrift files. Current implementation looks good personally but as others said it might be a quite difficult. WDYT?
@seung-00 @tbonelee Can you verify the change again?

> To address the above issue, I think we should separate the optional dependencies into individual modules, then we can eliminate them in some interpreters, but is zeppelin-protocol that case? I think it is required by all interpreters.

Yes, you're right. It should be mandatory for all interpreters for now. However, it was because we only provide all functions within the zeppelin-interpreter module. If we provided them as a zeppelin-protocol including definition, I believe that we might have different python interpreter implementation like pure python module. :-) I want to give some chance to utilize thrift definition as contributors want to use. It's the first step. I don't know the future yet but I believe that it gives more choice to the community.

> I fully agree with that, and I also noticed the packaging time for zeppelin-interpreter-shaded is pretty slow due to a lot of classes needing to be relocated, and some of those deps come from [ZEPPELIN-3471](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ZEPPELIN-3471), I have raised a [thread](https://lists.apache.org/thread/vm2m4xg6bg0db33txrrm9ydd15dqy1lx) to remove it in the dev mailing list, please leave your comments to help the community make the decision.

For the raft issue, let's move to the next step 👍

Thanks, merged to master
@pan3793 Thank you for your review. :)
Strongly +1 for making the Angular UI as default even though there are some bugs need to be fixed, and renaming the existing one to "Classic UI".
Thanks, merged to master
I like it! Thank you! One more thing, I hope we simplify the FIFO FAIR scheduler code as well. :-)

Additionally, I made the following changes:
1. Added the `web-classic` profile, removed the `web-angular` profile, and changed the default UI included during the build to the new UI (formerly included in `web-angular` profile).
2. Renamed configuration variable names:
   - `zeppelin.war` -> `zeppelin.classic.war`
   - `zeppelin.angular.war` -> `zeppelin.war`
3. Renamed module names:
   - `zeppelin-web` -> `zeppelin-web-classic`
   - `zeppelin-web-angular` -> `zeppelin-web`

> I hope we simplify the FIFO FAIR scheduler code as well. :-)

In my opinion, the code is quite simple. What are you thinking of?
code changes lgtm, I have not tested it locally though.

The code changes are now much clearer. @tbonelee Please perform a rebase to the current master branch, as there are merge conflicts. Furthermore, I think the Selenium tests for the “Classic” UI need to be adjusted.

I have a question. In this PR, will we permanently change the default web to a new one? I intended to release two versions with an old and new UI separately. After releasing 0.12.0 with those manners we can try to change the default UI for the 0.13.0 release in my understanding. WDYT?

@jongyoul The current release bundles both classic and new UI, and allows users to switch to each other by clicking a button, the proposed approach "change new UI to default UI" looks straightforward to me, and users still have the option to switch back to the classic UI by just clicking a button if they find bugs in the new UI.

> @jongyoul The current release bundles both classic and new UI, and allows users to switch to each other by clicking a button, the proposed approach "change new UI to default UI" looks straightforward to me, and users still have the option to switch back to the classic UI by just clicking a button if they find bugs in the new UI.

Yes, right. we can switch for now but I think it would be better to change gradually so my idea is to provide a new version with a separate package like zeppelin-bin-new-ui.tgz and so on for the next release. Then, we can check the community's feedback and change the default permanently.

>In my opinion, the code is quite simple. What are you thinking of?

I don't mean that this PR. Just sharing the information with you.

I would have liked more feedback from the community and improvements with the current solution. Unfortunately, there was only sporadic feedback.
I see the change of user interfaces as uncritical, especially as it is easy to switch between the two.
In my opinion, a separate release makes the release process and implementation unnecessarily complicated.
Yes, I hope so. For the release project, we can edit the release script to release two versions but we still need to change some code in ZeppelinServer and so on.

The `pty4j` version 0.12.35 is not compatible with the current version of Java used in Zeppelin.
Additionally, the latest `pty4j` version that is compatible with Zeppelin's Java version, 0.11.5 does not work on M1 Macs.
(Although the `pty4j` code has been updated to support macOS arm64, it doesn't seem to work for some reason.)
Therefore, unless we replcae the library with another one, this library upgrade can be applied after Zepplin's Java version is upgraded to 11 or higher.
For now, I will close this PR.

According to https://github.com/JetBrains/pty4j/issues/82#issuecomment-835443203

> M1 processors were supported in https://github.com/JetBrains/pty4j/commit/4fd4f84d701f3418539c59322f5ae674e4e92cec (included in pty4j version 0.11.3 or higher).

Can we try this version? https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.jetbrains.pty4j/pty4j/0.12.10-jdk8
Thanks, merged to master
